Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: RUI: Dynamic Mathematical Modeling Towards Understanding Information Diffusion in Online Social Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Online social networks have played an increasingly important role in connecting people and spreading information. It becomes urgent and necessary to understand the information diffusion process over large scale online social networks. However, due to the intricacy of human dynamics and social interactions, the vast scale of users and information, and the heterogeneity and diversity of online social networks, understanding information diffusion in social networks remains a daunting task. The PIs explore one key question in this project: how does a piece of information travel over time and space in an online social network. Similar questions have been asked and investigated for the outbreak of epidemics, but little attempt has been made in online social networks to model the diffusion of information from both temporal and spatial dimensions due to the challenges in quantitatively modeling the diffusion process in online social networks. The PIs combine the advances in data mining, graph theory, and dynamic mathematical modeling, specifically partial differential equation modeling, to characterize and predict the temporal and spatial dynamics of information diffusion.

Broader impact: This work not only builds the first extendable theoretical framework for characterizing, modeling and predicting the diffusion process of information with dynamic mathematical modeling approach, but also helps facilitate the spreading of positive information and limit the distribution of unwanted misinformation such as spam and phishing messages because it can gain an in-depth understanding of information diffusion in social networks. Moreover, this project provides an opportunity for undergraduate students to gain valuable research experiences in mathematical modeling, graph theory and large scale data collection and analysis, and to prepare them for the challenges and opportunities in the increasingly important field of online social networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project demonstrated the feasibility of modeling information diffusion from both temporal and spatial dimension and provided foundations and vocabularies for characterizing, modeling, and predicting the diffusion process of information spreading over online social networks. We have proposed several PDE models to describe and predict the diffusion and experimented with different distance definitions on social media, including friendship hop, shared interest, community membership, and geographical proximity. We also provided insight into information diffusion from multiple sources.

 

Furthermore, we built a Twitter analysis and modeling framework which includes tweets stream collection, keyword collection, user follower collection, tweets filtering, geo-tagging tweets, source tweets extraction, user interaction extraction, and community detection. We shared the codes on github. Using the collection tools, we collected an Arizona Twitter following topology with about 1.5 million Arizona users and collected flu tweets information over three months.

 

We provided research opportunities for 10 undergraduate students in Applied Computing Program and Applied Math Program at ASU West, including minority students and student with disability. The students contributed to the research by implementing the modules in our Twitter analysis and modeling framework. All students presented their work in ASU New College student research poster sessions. The students gained research, programming, and reporting skills in this project that lead them to graduate school or become a programmer.  They also got the opportunity to work with people from different disciplines since this project involves researchers from computer science, math, and sociology.

 

In addition to publishing over 15 journal and conference articles, we also developed two undergraduate-level courses in social media modeling and big data and modeling based on our research. We had a book under contract resultant from a compilation of research publications from this project. We also build a project web page to disseminate our findings and visualization of diffusion.
